awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Investigating the "Grand Challenge" Solutions of Agro-Food Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research project focuses on the food-technology sector in the San Francisco Bay Area. It will examine the interests, principles, social relationships, and institutional forces that are guiding the sector as a whole within the region. The project will use multiple methods including database construction, network analysis, surveys of patents, observations of trade meetings, and interviews to shed light on how entrepreneurs are anticipating public resistance or support in the design and marketing of their products. The results of this project will have the potential to lead to reconsiderations of problem framing, product design and marketing. It may serve to encourage philanthropists and public institutions to invest in solutions most likely to be efficacious, equitable, and widely embraced. It may also serve to generate a more nuanced public engagement with these technologies that steer clear of the extremes of knee jerk rejection and uncritical celebration. 

This project will investigate a broad array of novel food, supply chain, and agricultural technologies. The aim of the project is to produce understanding of the challenges facing the agro-food system. It will examine the discursive frames and enabling assumptions that underpin technology deployment, and it will explore how these technologies are being shaped by institutional collaborations and in response to imagined publics. Specific research activities include constructing a database of existing and pipeline technologies, producing a social network analysis of influences and connections, observing the self-representations of both the sector and individual products at industry trade meetings and other events, and interviewing a broad array of entrepreneurs and collaborating scientists and funders. By subjecting the assumptions and promises of a broad array of novel technologies to robust social analysis and sharing the results with the industry and its champions, this project will help technology entrepreneurs and their collaborators to acquire a better understanding of the nature of their own interventions, how they align with their own stated aims, and the underlying issues that might inform public perception and resistance to the disruptions they propose.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The tech sector’s revolutionizing capacities in computing and biotechnology, along with a widespread faith that societal problem-solving is best left to the private sector, has created a wide opening for tech sector involvement in one of the most critical and complex domains of human existence. Since 2013, private investment in agri-food technologies has skyrocketed, funding thousands of start-ups, with many based in or coming through Silicon Valley. This project examined the Silicon Valley-based tech sector’s claims and ostensible efforts to address the major social and ecological challenges confronting food systems: climate change, food security, environmental sustainability, human and animal health. We investigated the origins of the tech sector’s involvement in this domain and the array of technologies and solutions that have been developed under that umbrella. We asked how 1) entrepreneurs developed their specific solutions; 2) the funding mechanisms and cultures of the tech sector shape these solutions; 3) the sector encounters and addresses the unique aspects of food and agriculture; and 4) the sector imagines and anticipates public response to their technologies. Drawing upon sector-published market maps, existing databases, and event programs, we constructed and analyzed a database of all agri-food oriented companies that came through Silicon Valley between 2016 and 2020. We attended nearly 100 events, watched dozens of pitches, conducted over 90 interviews with startups, investors, industry advocates and analysts, and conducted content analyses of dozens of web pages, news articles, and reports promoting these solutions. Studying across the sector, rather than focusing on only one area of innovation, allowed us to see patterns and dynamics that other social science scholarship has missed.

So-called alternative proteins, referring to protein-forward products made with unusual ingredients and a variety of cellular, acellular, and extrusion processes, have received outsized attention and funding, largely because they substitute for animal-based foods from highly controversial conventional livestock production. However, the majority of products being developed draw on fairly typical Silicon Valley expertise in computing, data analytics, and automation. Developers of these digital applications claim to solve problems in farm management, labor shortages, waste and inefficiencies in supply chains, and everyday transactions for food and farming businesses. Consumer packaged goods, most without any high-tech component, have a surprisingly large presence in the sector, suggesting that sector hype has provided new marketing opportunities for otherwise common products. Equally surprising is how few biotechnology-based farming treatments are present in the sector.

Despite some genuine interest in addressing food systems problems, our study found that—as a whole—Silicon Valley expertise, hype culture, and funding models are largely ill-suited for this task. For example, many of the food system’s problems are inextricably linked to social and political issues that “techno-fixes” alone cannot address. More pointedly, many food system problems—from pests to human nutrition to depleted soils—are biophysically-based, requiring direct treatments, whereas the digital technologies that dominate the sector, inherited from Silicon Valley’s legacy industries, can provide only information and business efficiency. In general, entrepreneurs and investors alike persistently ignore the myriad ways in which food and agriculture differs from industry. As a result, they introduce technologies that potentially retrench problems of past technological introductions, such as digital applications geared to enhance productivity, while ignoring the historic problems such as over-production of crops that have contributed to declining profits for farmers.

Silicon Valley’s hype culture, often distilled in the ubiquitous funding pitch, works at odds with meaningful problem-solving. In an effort to attract funding and general interest, agri-food tech entrepreneurs tend to over-promise while simultaneously occluding what they can deliver. For example, producers of alternative proteins promise to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the use of core resources such as land and water; yet, they obscure the land, energy, ore, and food resources that are needed to produce food in bioreactors. Too, entrepreneurs show scant interest or involvement with their publics and, hence, any interest in pre-empting potential public concern. Instead, they project consumer needs and desires instrumentally, to make sense of their technologies for a venture capital audience.

Silicon Valley’s funding model also hinders meaningfully addressing food system problems. Despite widespread rhetoric championing the disruption of established, culpable industries, success for start-ups often revolves on an exit involving incumbent corporations. Moreover, they often depend on incumbent expertise in product formulation, extension, and marketing. As such, established agribusiness’s involvement in the sector is significant and growing, leading to a situation of co-existence with rather than replacement of current systems.

Today’s food system problems require workable solutions. But the agri-food tech sector—with its demands for entrepreneurial profitability, eschewing of regulations, and shunning of social and historical analysis—is unlikely to deliver them. It is imperative to approach food system change with wide public involvement, the intellectual work of the social sciences, and funding structures that support the most efficacious approaches rather than promulgating technologies that may be better suited to science fiction.
